feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 01 at 3:50PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Strong Storm Impacting West Coast of Alaska Friday... A strong storm bringing winds, snow and blowing snow will move north over the West Coast of Alaska on Friday. There is a possibility that this storm could bring blizzard conditions to the West Coast Friday into Saturday. This could also bring a slight chance of freezing rain to areas south of Nome on Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baldwin Peninsula and Selawik Valley; Chukchi Sea Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Lower Kobuk and Noatak Valleys; Northern and Interior Seward Peninsula; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; St Lawrence Island and Bering Strait Coast; Yukon Delta

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued March 01 at 12:37PM PST until March 02 at 9:00PM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and breaking waves are expected due to elevated surf of 4 to 6 feet with local sets to 7 feet. Surf will be highest on west facing beaches. * WHERE...Ventura County Coast.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued March 01 at 12:07PM PST until March 02 at 4:00AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH EARLY WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Surf of 4 to 6 feet and associated high rip current risk. * WHERE...San Diego County Beaches. Highest surf south of Del Mar.

entry.summary: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM EST WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents. * WHERE...Southeast Georgia and Northeast Florida Beaches. * WHEN...Until 4 AM EST Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued March 01 at 7:14PM EST until March 04 at 7:00AM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM EST WEDNESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected. * WHERE...Coastal Palm Beach, Coastal Broward and Coastal Miami- Dade Counties. * WHEN...From 7 AM EST Wednesday through Friday morning.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued March 01 at 4:17AM EST until March 02 at 4:00AM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT... * WHAT...Gusty north to northwest winds will produce a longshore current with rough surf and breaking waves of 4 to 6 feet. There will also be a Moderate risk of dangerous rip currents. * WHERE...Southern Brevard, Indian River, St. Lucie, Martin, Coastal Volusia and Northern Brevard Counties.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Volusia; Indian River; Martin; Northern Brevard County; Southern Brevard County; St. Lucie

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued March 02 at 3:22AM ChST until March 03 at 6:00AM ChST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH RISK OF RIP CURRENTS THROUGH LATE TONIGHT... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents. * WHERE...East facing reefs of the Marianas. * WHEN...Through late Wednesday night. * IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 01 at 6:48PM ChST until March 02 at 7:00PM ChST by NWS
entry.summary: ...STRONG DAYTIME WINDS AND DRY CONDITIONS MAY LEAD TO RAPID FIRE SPREAD ACROSS PARTS OF GUAM... ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING... * WIND...Sustained 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 30 mph during the afternoon through Wednesday. * HUMIDITY...As low as 55 to 60 percent in the afternoon.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 28 at 12:44PM MST by NWS
entry.summary: Above freezing temperatures combined with a very wet subtropical system, may cause rapid melt off of snowpack below 5000 feet. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 01 at 1:27PM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAVY RAINFALL SUNDAY NIGHT INTO TUESDAY MORNING HAS LED TO AN INCREASED THREAT OF LANDSLIDES AND DEBRIS FLOWS IN WESTERN WASHINGTON... Rainfall of as much as 3 to 10 inches over the past 72 hours has increased soil moisture to high levels across western Washington. This amount of rain has put extra pressure on soil instability,

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 01 at 10:16AM PST until March 02 at 5:53AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. * WHERE...A portion of west central Washington, including the following county, Lewis. * WHEN...Through Wednesday afternoon.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 01 at 9:51AM PST until March 03 at 7:03AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...The National Weather Service in Spokane WA has issued a Flood Watch for the following rivers in Washington...Idaho... Palouse River near Potlatch affecting Latah and Whitman Counties. ...The Flood Watch is extended for the following rivers in Idaho... Coeur d Alene River at Cataldo affecting Kootenai and Shoshone Counties.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 01 at 8:54AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...RISING RIVER LEVELS THROUGH MIDWEEK DUE TO RAIN AND HIGH SNOW LEVELS... For the Foothills of the northern Blue Mountains, the northern Blue Mountains and the Grande Ronde Valley. Southwest flow will continue to bring periods of rain to northeast Oregon and southeast Washington through midweek.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Foothills of the Blue Mountains of Washington; Northwest Blue Mountains

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 1:45PM PST until March 02 at 5:11AM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...The National Weather Service in Pendleton OR has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Naches River near Cliffdell affecting Yakima County. For the Naches River...including Cliffdell, Naches...Minor flooding is forecast. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/pdt.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 01 at 8:05AM MST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Strong Winds Expected Through the Day... This is a special weather statement from the National Weather Service Office in Riverton. * WHAT...Strong west to northwest winds gusting 50 to 60 mph in the mountains, and 40 to 50 mph in the lower elevations around Dubois and Cody.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Absaroka Mountains; Cody Foothills; Upper Wind River Basin; Wind River Mountains East
